comments.author: fanny
comments.content: I love the idea. which will certainly happen tomorrow or sometimes in the very near future in my kitchen. xx

comments.author: Ivy Manning
comments.content: Niice! I just did a little article on the same for the Oregonian. Love the idea of mussels marineieres sans the mussels. Never likes those nasty bivalves. Thanks for inspiration!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Readers - Here's Ivy's article: http://www.oregonlive.com/foodday/index.ssf/2011/05/the_artful_artichoke.html - terrific background on artichoke varieties and several delicious looking recipes!

comments.author: Courteney @ Not a "diet" blog
comments.content: Lovely! I'm going to be featuring artichokes again soon and am excited to see all that others are doing with the vegetable, I feel that in many circles its a bit misunderstood ;-).

comments.author: Hisham Soliman
comments.content: Oh wow. These look fancy. But also really really good. Thanks for sharing!

comments.author: M. @ v-gourmet.com
comments.content: Have you ever tried cooking artichokes in a broth infused with liquid smoke? It adds a really interesting flavor. I recently did a recipe with a smokey-berbere broth, and it was a really nice break from the more traditional artichoke flavors. I love seeing recipes for anything other than "steam and serve with butter," though, and this one looks fabulous.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: The smoky broth sounds interesting! I reckon you could do something similar by actually smoking them before or after a steam to cook through.

comments.author: Katherine
comments.content: Love the inspiration! The recipe is somewhat similar to artichokes alla Romana. They look absolutely delicious, and the baby purple artichokes are gorgeous.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks, Katherine! I'm loving the photos of Mahane Yehuda on your blog.

comments.author: Jen
comments.content: That does sound delicious. As a vegetarian, I love employing meat-related cooking techniques for veggies. Great idea. I need to keep my eyes open for purple artichokes at farmers markets here in Portland.
